newsitem.title: INDIA: INDIAN RUPEE ENDS UP VS DLR IN SPOT, QUIET IN FWD.
newsitem.headline: INDIAN RUPEE ENDS UP VS DLR IN SPOT, QUIET IN FWD.

text.p: The Indian rupee ended Thursday stronger at 35.7125/7175 per dollar against opening quotes of 35.725/730 in two-way trade, dealers said.
They said the rupee initially weakened on corporate demand but dollar sales by exporters helped it rally.
The rupee traded at a high of 35.7175 and a low of 35.73 per dollar on Thursday.
"There was some demand from Bombay-based foreign banks and this pushed the rupee down initially," said a dealer at a state-run bank.
"State Bank of India was also bidding. But later on there were good dollar sales from exporters which helped the rupee end stronger than opening quotes," he said.
The dealer said Thursday's fluctuations in the exchange rate were on expected lines.
"We knew there would be some demand ahead of the extended weekend and also that exporters will sell at higher levels," he said.
The forex market is closed on Friday as banks are shut for the Independence Day holiday. The market reopens on Monday.
Dealers said the rupee was little changed against the forward dollar in quiet, range-bound trade.
"Rates went up marginally on tighter domestic liquidity," said a dealer at a state-run bank.
The annualised premium on six-month dollars ended at 4.59 percent against its previous close of 4.53 percent.
